name: swirled
content:

past simple and past participle of
swirl
[ I or T, usually + adv/prep ] to move quickly with a twisting, circular movement, or to make something do this: The fog swirled thickly around us. Swirl a little oil around the frying pan. Synonym
eddy
[ I ] If ideas or stories about somebody or something swirl, they are often heard but may not be based on fact or may not always say the same thing: Rumours have swirled for years that he is on the point of retiring. Much of the controversy that swirls around her ignores the actual content of her work. Compare
spread verb
More examplesFewer examplesThick cigar smoke swirled as the men drank whisky.The overflowing river swirled around them.Try swirling some cream into scrambled eggs.Accusations swirled around Washington last week of partisan vendettas and turf wars. Already, speculation is swirling that the company is a takeover target.Conflicting reports have swirled around the status of the Secretary of State.
